description: Partly from Middle English pleder, pledere, equivalent to plead +‎ -er; and partly from Middle English pledour, plaidour, from Anglo-Norman plaidur, pledour, Old French plaidëor, pledëor.

entries.meaning: (law) a person who pleads in court; an advocate [from 13th c.]
examples: ‘Soon after I came out I asked one of the pleaders to have a smoke with me – only a cigarette, mind.’

entries.meaning: (generally) someone who pleads or implores [from 16th c.]
